Topic.Title: The educated states vote for Obama. Shouldn't the educated states be weighted more heavily than the red states anyway

Message.Msg: I see you miss the point again. Of course every occupation has specific training. This is not relevant at all. Is it not obvious to you that people differ in their capabilities some being more capable than others. Not everybody can be a computer programmer but most could be a farmer with sufficient 'education'. It is precisely this scarcity of innate ability that determines wages and earnings. I shouldn't have to explain this to a conservative. Yes i dodged the question about fundamental needs to survival because it is irrelevant. You see we have this thing called money and it acts as a motivator for people to enter any profession that has a scarcity. Using naive logic the same argument can be made that 'garbage collectors' are just as vital to a society as farmers because we could not live in our own garbage. But wait you will say if some don't collect garbage others will, same with farmers. True value in the new economy is being able to do conceptually difficult things. Stuff done in blue states.

Topic.Title: The educated states vote for Obama. Shouldn't the educated states be weighted more heavily than the red states anyway

Message.Msg: "While I agree it's synergistic, see my reply, which of the two could and has existed without the other? Who is essential, who is not?" Which brings us back to one dimensional fallacious reasoning. A century ago before the rise and preeminence of "agribusiness" in our food supply chain, the producers of perishable food stuffs were local. Now they are global. In that bygone era, the broker had no role at all because produce was localized in terms of cultivation, distribution (farmers' markets and self/family peddled) and consumption. This is no longer the case and the commodity brokers' importance as a cog in the modern machine that is "agribusiness" can no longer be minimized. Once again, think 21st century. You can NOT turn back the clock to suit your archaic philosophy regarding good governance in the interest of ALL the people. Refer to my previous post re the preamble to our constitution.

Message.Title: The heartfelt liberal mind
Message.Msg: To all the millions of victims of superstorm Sandy, Chris Matthews has a message: "I'm so glad." The MSNBC host, on a panel of pro-Obama pundits including Rachel Maddow, ended election coverage overnight by saying he's "glad" the storm hit, suggesting it served a greater good by boosting President Obama to a second term. "I'm so glad we had that storm last week," Matthews said, after interjecting to give some final thoughts. Somebody off-screen could be heard saying "ooo" at that remark, but Matthews confidently put his hand up to explain. It's always been about Obama not the people. Same reason he didn't send help to Benghazi

Topic.Title: Mooche's Vacation Schedule

Message.Msg: Hey, Idiot. "Reagan played to the crowds during speeches and was the first president to use his television appearances to his utmost advantage. His political presence was unlike anything Americans had encountered before. Much of that presence was the result of Nancy Reagan's endeavors to glamorize the First Family. Mrs. Reagan had never fallen out of love with the dazzle, glitz, and elegance of the Hollywood lifestyle she and her husband had abandoned in the 1960s. Because she found the White House décor somewhat drab, she spent hundreds of thousands of dollars revamping and redecorating the White House to make it more of a palace than a presidential mansion. Nancy threw many extravagant parties and invited all their old friends. Actor Jimmy Stewart, for example, visited occasionally. With so many famous people visiting the Reagan's, the White House quickly became the center of the social scene in Washington D.C. Not since the days of John F. Kennedy had the White House been such a lively place."

Topic.Title: Mooche's Vacation Schedule

Message.Msg: Hey, Idiot. "With this first state dinner, Nancy Reagan showed that she understood the connection between the political and the social, and that she was determined to restore glamour and excitement to the White House—elements many felt had been lacking since the days of Jacqueline Kennedy. According to White House chief usher Rex Scouten, she took an intense interest in every detail of every state dinner, from the food and flowers to the seating and entertainment. She increased the number of state dinners to nearly one a month, and cut back the guest lists from 130 to 96 so that they would feel more like private parties. “The Reagans had such ease as hosts,” Brandon adds. “Mrs. Reagan always said to me, ‘Muffie, these parties have to be fun.’”

Topic.Title: Rush Limpballs: 'Romney wasn't conservative enough'

Message.Msg: You may have a point. Who will pay for all of those free cell phones that the government is giving out? Who will pay Solyndra? Without Pell grants and student loans, students may have to go to community colleges or the more expensive colleges may have to find a way to reduce costs. Without grants these colleges may even have to forego studying the mating habits of whatever animals. The government may even have to reduce its stock of empty office buildings and warehouses. And (horrors), NPR may have to forego its subsidy.

Message.Title: Mileage flap could cost Hyundai, Kia millions. GALDURN GOBBERMENT REGULATORS!!!
Message.Msg: Mileage flap could cost Hyundai, Kia millions Forced to restate mileage claims after a government audit, Hyundai and its Korean sibling Kia could be in a world of financial hurt – even as they struggle to overcome the potential damage to their image which, in recent years, has put an emphasis on delivering industry benchmark fuel economy. THIS THE KIND OF GOVERNMENT REGULATION RIGHTWING NUTS JOBS HAVE BEEN COMPLAINING ABOUT. THAT GALD DURN GUBBERMENT MAKES AUTO MANUFACTURERS STATE THEIR MILEAGE PERFORMANCE ACCURATELY.
